abstract.p: Hussein Quli Khan informs the officials and residents of disctrict (pargana) Askarabad that Reza Ali's claim to a grant of land for taking care of the mosque is true. Therefore, no one should trouble Reza Ali regarding his right to the land. The document was copied in a British colonial collector's office, likely at some point in the nineteenth century.

p.note: The text is written in a cursive script and is partially covered by a paperweight.
The faint and illegible inscription appears to be bi-lingual in Persian and Bengali.

Copy.
A sanad with the seal of Nawab Hussein Quli KhanNaib Nazim of Bengal under Ali Vardi Khan, governor of Dhaka issued on the first of the month of Rajab, 2nd regnal yearThe Gregorian date of 1750 has been assigned based on the fact that Nawab Hussein Quli Khan (d. 1755) was active in the middle of the eighteenth century, and thus this document was likely composed during the reign of the Mughal Emperor Ahmad Shah (r. 1748–54). and the details are [as follows]: the mutasaddis of current and future affairs,
the chaudhris and qanungos and peasants and agriculturists of pargana Askarabad, sarkar Islamabad should know that, since Reza Ali has made it apparent that
the amount ofnine kanisKani is a local unit of measurement in the Chittagong and Tripura areas of Bengal. Reading kindly provided by Richard Eaton. of land, exempt from taxes except imperial is allocated from within the said pargana to the applicant for reason of taking care of a mosque on account of the orders of the governors
of the past. He hopes that an order sealed by the government for the end of harassment will be kindly awarded. Therefore, on the basis of checks
the declaration of the said person was found to be true. Hence, the said land is allocated and appointed for the custody of the mosque, so that
the said person, taking possession of the said land, can use the collections from therein for lighting lamps, the daily allowance of the sermon-giver and the caller to prayer,
and sweeping and coming and going [i.e., hospitality for travellers] etc., legitimate [activities] of the mosque [and] engage himself in saying prayers for the state of His Lordship Zill-i SubhaniI.e., the Shadow of God, likely a reference to the Mughal emperor. This honorific text is elevated and written to the left of the seal.
No one should give him trouble on account of the document of favour of the land assessment, etc. Knowing all the injunctions to be applicable in this matter, do as written.

p.note: The text is written in Bengali, in a cursive hand the team has not been able to decipher.
